Graphical abstract Carbon covered hydrotalcite (CCHT) supported Ru catalysts with single (Cs or Ba) and double (Cs and Ba) promoters were prepared by two different methods viz., impregnation (IMP) and polyol reduction (PR) methods using ethylene glycol as solvent. The performance of the catalysts for ammonia synthesis was carried out in the temperature range of 523–698K at atmospheric pressure. The following sequence with respect to the % NH3 (volume/volume) formation was observed; BaRuCCHT-IMP<BaRuCCHT-PR<CsBaRuCCHT-IMP<CsRuCCHT-IMP<CsRuCCHT-PR<CsBaRuCCHT-PR. XRD, TEM, N2-adsorption, H2-TPR, CO chemisorption and TPD of H2 and CO2 techniques were used to investigate the physico-chemical properties of the catalysts and also to establish the reasons responsible for superior catalytic activity of CsBaRuCCHT-PR catalyst. The CO chemisorption and TEM studies revealed that CsBaRuCCHT-PR catalyst possessed the high active Ru metal surface area and small particle size. The highest activity of this catalyst could be attributed to high surface area, low particle size, high active surface metal (Ru) area, and strong Ru–CCHT interaction. Keywords Carbon covered hydrotalcite Impregnation Polyol reduction Ru-support interaction Ammonia synthesis 1 Introduction Supported and promoted Ru based catalysts are highly active in ammonia synthesis under mild conditions than conventional multi-promoted iron catalysts, which are commonly used in industrial process [1–3]. The function of a support in a catalyst performance is one of the important factors in catalysis. The support can influence the catalytic activity of Ru catalysts by modifying the electronic properties of the active Ru metal particles; by affecting the growth, structure and morphology of the active particles that are responsible for changing the abundance of the active sites of the catalyst [4]. Ru catalysts supported on the thermally modified active carbon have been proved to be much more active than fused iron catalysts [5]. Significant attention has been turned over to the carbon supported Ru systems promoted with alkali and barium atoms to obtain efficient catalyst for synthesis of ammonia. However, the studies showed that the deactivation of catalyst is a serious problem under the reaction conditions, when Ru is deposited on the surface of activated carbon support. Metal sintering, loss of active component and methanation of the support are the three major problems identified for the deactivation of the catalyst. The methanation of support becomes obvious, when Ru containing catalyst was operated under reaction conditions for a long time due to Ru is known to be an excellent catalyst of the carbon substrate methanation [6–10]. Some other supports such as SiO2 [11] MgO [12–14], alumina [15–19] and zeolites [20,21] have been investigated as supports for Ru catalysts in ammonia synthesis. An alternative carbon, HSAG (high surface area graphite) material was reported as an efficient and stable support [22]. Decades ago, Rao et al. [23–25] prepared carbon coated alumina catalysts by pyrolysis of an alkene on alumina support. The authors observed that the carbon coated alumina not only can eliminate the disadvantages of the low strength of carbon and the acidity of alumina, but also offers the advantages of the electron withdrawing capacity of carbon and the stability of alumina support. It was also reported that Ru supported on carbon-covered alumina (CCA) offered the purity of carbon and eliminates the acidity of alumina to overcome the existed drawbacks [23–25]. Mg–Al hydrotalcite precursor supported Ru catalyst has been reported as a very efficient catalyst for ammonia synthesis at atmospheric pressure [26]. It was also observed that alkaline-earth metal oxides can reduce the agglomeration of Ru particles at high temperatures, which increases the amount of available Ru [27]. We previously reported that the double metal (Cs and Ba) promoted Ru catalyst supported with hydrotalcite precursor enhances the catalytic activity for ammonia synthesis [28]. Recently, Lin et al. [29] synthesized Ru supported carbon-covered alumina catalysts for the ammonia synthesis. The authors observed that carbon in carbon-covered alumina support inhibited the adsorption of the hydrogen species for chlorine-free Ru catalysts, but did not observed any change in their catalytic activity patterns. On the other hand, presence of carbon can increase the ammonia synthesis activities of containing-chlorine Ru catalysts by decreasing the disadvantageous effect of chlorine on H2 adsorption. Very recently, Zi-qing et al. [30] utilized the super basic KOH–ZrO2 to support Ru-based catalyst for ammonia synthesis. This catalyst showed high catalytic activity for ammonia synthesis. Such high activity was attributed to highly dispersed particle of Ru together with the appropriate Ru particles size on the support and the strong basicity after KOH loading. However, stability of catalyst under high pressure of hydrogen remains a key issue. The main objective of this work is to study the effect of carbon covered hydrotalcite (HT) supported Ru catalysts with Cs or Ba promoter and Cs and Ba promoters for ammonia synthesis at low temperatures under atmospheric pressure. The other objectives of this study are to investigate the role of metal particle size, basicity and reducibility by carbon coverage on calcined hydrotalcite support. H2 and CO2-temperature programmed desorption experiments were carried out to obtain the information about adsorption state of hydrogen and basic properties of supported Ru catalysts with single and double promoters prepared by impregnation and polyol reduction methods. An effort was made to correlate the physico-chemical properties of the catalysts with catalytic activity for ammonia synthesis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of CCHT support and Ru supported CCHT catalysts The Mg–Al hydrotalcite (HT, Mg/Al=2) support was prepared by co-precipitation under super saturation conditions and calcined at 723K for 18h [31]. Carbon covered hydrotalcite (CCHT) support was obtained by pyrolysis of cyclohexene on HT at 873K as described in previous reports [32–34]. The Ru supported CCHT catalyst was prepared by impregnating the CCHT with 10wt% aqueous solution of RuCl3∙3H2O (Loba Chemie, India). The excess of the water was removed using a rotary evaporator and the dried catalyst was designated as RuCCHT-Imp. Alternatively, Ru supported CCHT catalyst was prepared by polyol reduction method [RuCCHT-PR] using ethylene glycol as solvent as described in the report by Herrmann et al. [35]. The single promoted (Cs or Ba) and double promoted (Cs and Ba) Ru supported CCHT catalysts were prepared as described in our previous publication [28]. The cesium promoted Ru CCHT catalysts by impregnation and polyol reduction methods were designated as CsRuCCHT-IMP and CsRuCCHT-PR respectively and similarly barium promoted catalysts were designated as BaRuCCHT-IMP and BaRuCCHT-PR respectively. The double promoted (Cs and Ba) catalysts by impregnation and polyol reduction methods were designated as CsBaRuCCHT-IMP and CsBaRuCCHT-PR respectively. In all single promoted catalysts the Ru:Cs/Ba:support weight ratio was kept as 10:51:100 and in double promoted catalyst the Ru:Cs:Ba:support was kept as 10:25.5:25.5:100. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts X-ray diffraction patterns of the reduced single and double promoted Ru supported CCHT catalysts were recorded on Rigaku Miniflex (M/S. Rigaku Corporation-Japan) instrument using Ni filtered Cu-Kα radiation (1.5405Å), with a scan speed of 2°min−1 and a scan range of 2–80° at 30kV and 15mA. The identification of different crystalline phases in the samples was performed by comparing the data with the ICDD files. The morphological features of the catalysts were monitored using a JEOL JEM 2000EXII transmission electron microscope, operating between 160 and 180kV. The specimens were prepared by dispersing the samples in methanol using ultrasonic bath and evaporating a drop of resultant suspension onto the lacey carbon support grid. Textural properties of the synthesized samples were determined from nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms measurements at 77K using Autosorb Automated Gas Sorption System (Quantachrome USA). Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) profiles of the single and double promoted catalysts were generated using an on-line quartz micro reactor interfaced with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) of a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, model: GC-17A, Japan) and the profiles were recorded using a GC software Class-GC10. A gas mixture (10vol.% of H2 and balance Ar) was used as the reducing gas while the catalyst was heated at a linear heating ramp of 10Kmin−1 from 303 to 973K. The CO chemisorption experiments were carried out at 303K using a pulse reactor to determine the Ru metal area and Ru metal particle size. In a typical experiment, approximately 150mg of the catalyst sample was loaded in a micro quartz reactor (8mm i.d., and 250mm long) and the catalyst sample was first reduced under a hydrogen flow at 723K for 2h, and kept at the same temperature for 1h under He flow and then the reactor was cooled to 303K under helium gas flow. The outlet of the reactor was connected to a micro-thermal conductivity detector (TCD) of GC-17A (Shimadzu Instruments, Japan) through an automatic six-port valve (Valco Instruments USA). After cooling of the sample to 303K, pulses of gas (10% CO balance He) were injected through a 1mL loop connected to the six-port valve until no further change in the intensity of TCD peak due to gas pulse. CO2-temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) technique was employed to evaluate basic site distribution of the catalysts. Prior to the CO2-TPD experiment, the catalyst was reduced under H2 flow at 723K for 2h and the gas flow was changed to helium gas and treated the sample for 1h and then 10% CO2 balance He mixture has been adsorbed on pretreated catalyst at 333K in pulses through a six-port valve similar to that of CO chemisorption. After the completion of the pulse chemisorption the reactor temperature was brought up to 373K and flushed with helium gas for 1h to remove the physisorbed CO2. The temperature is then increased linearly at a programmed rate of 10Kmin−1 from 373 to 973K at which 30min isothermal conditions were maintained, followed by cooling to room temperature. TCD signal was recorded using the software to obtain the CO2-TPD pattern for all the samples. H2-TPD experiments were also carried out to determine the hydrogen adsorption capacities of the catalysts. Approximately 0.15g of catalyst was loaded in a quartz reactor (12mm outer diameter). The chemisorption experiments were performed similar to that of CO2-TPD, but the H2 gas adsorption was carried out at temperature of 303K. After adsorption, the catalyst was flushed with Ar gas to remove the physisorbed H2 for 30min. The temperature was then increased linearly at a programmed rate of 10Kmin−1 from 303 to 973K at which 30min isothermal conditions were maintained. 2.3 Ammonia synthesis Activity tests over single and double promoted catalysts prepared by both impregnation and polyol methods were carried out using a fixed bed glass micro-reactor (i.d. 18mm and 300mm long) at temperature ranging from 523 to 698K with a successive increment of 25K under atmospheric pressure. The total gas flow rate of 10,000mLh−1 with the stoichiometric ratio of N2:H2 =1:3 was used for the reaction. The generators, NG 2081 (Claind, Italy) and HOGEN GC300 (Proton Energy Systems, USA) were used for N2 and H2 gases respectively with >99.99% purity. Prior to the activity measurements the catalysts were reduced at 723K for 4h. The complete reduction of the catalyst was confirmed by testing the vent gas with silver nitrate solution for hydrochloric acid coming from Cl− ions and Nessler’s reagent for ammonia coming from NO3 − ions. The ammonia concentration at the outlet mixture was determined by neutralizing with a known volume of 0.01N aqueous H2SO4 solution at regular intervals. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 X-ray diffraction X-ray diffraction patterns of HT, HT calcined at 600°C and CCHT are shown in Fig. 1 (A). The as-synthesized MgAl-HT sample displayed the characteristic diffraction peaks at (003), (006), (009) and (113) reflections at 2θ =11.4, 22, 35, and 61.8° corresponding to MgAl-HT [36] with formula Mg6Al3(OH)6CO3∙4H2O. Upon being calcined in air at 600°C for 3h, MgAlHT sample lost its hydrotalcite-layered structure and was transformed into mixed oxides of Mg and Al as identified by two diffraction peaks at 2θ =43 and 63° [Fig. 1(A)]. The carbon covered HT sample at 600°C (CCHT) did not showed any clear diffraction peaks corresponding to mixed oxides of Mg and Al. Previously, Vissers et al. [33] observed that carbon deposition occurs indiscriminately and uniformly as a thin layer over the surface of alumina supports. A similar phenomenon could have happened in case HT support, however there is another possibility that the formed carbon from the pyrolysis of cyclohexene in the synthesis system could act as a diluent of crystalline mixed oxide phase resulting drastic decrease of crystallinity of the sample. The XRD patterns for the Ru supported samples prepared by impregnation method and polyol reduction method are depicted in Fig. 1(B) and (C) respectively. The samples prepared using impregnation method showed sharp and intense diffraction peaks due to three different phases; CsCl [d =2.90, 4.11, 1.68, 1.84 ICDD No. 730390], metallic Ru [d =2.06, 2.34, 2.14 ICDD No. 60,663] and BaCl2 [d =3.71, 2.87, 4.05 ICDD No. 240094]. Most intense diffraction peaks due to CsCl phase can be seen in Fig. 1(B), this observation indicates that Cl− was exchanged between Ru-metal and Cs-promoter in impregnated catalysts. It was reported that alkali promoters promote the activity not only by affecting the ruthenium surface electronically but also by neutralizing the Cl− presented in the RuCl3 precursor [12]. It appears that almost all the Cl− ions were removed from the Ru metal and this can be confirmed from the H2-TPR results. On the other hand, minor diffraction peaks corresponding to CsCl and BaCl2 phases were observed in XRD patterns of the samples presented in Fig. 1(C). The majority of the diffraction peaks are due to Ru-metal for these samples. This observation indicates very small amount of Cl− is presented along with Ru metal and/or alkali promoter in the catalysts prepared using polyol reduction method. Kurihara et al. [37] successfully synthesized nanosize powders of many metals including ruthenium using the polyol reduction method. The metal powders obtained by the polyol method are the result of the formation of metal nanoparticles and their aggregation. However, it was also reported that if the aggregation is avoided, the polyol reduction method can be used in the preparation of Ru colloids [38]. It appears that the polyol reduction method conditions used in the present study produced lower size nanoparticles of Ru than the impregnation method. 3.2 Transmission electron microscopy The morphological investigation of the catalysts was carried out by TEM analysis. The TEM images of representative catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . The images of the samples are clearly indicating the formation of well grown and regular shaped Ru metal particles (black spots) on the CCHT support, which is in accordance with the XRD results. The TEM images of RuCCHT-PR and CsRuCCHT-PR samples are showing the presence of many black and dispersed particles on the support (Fig. 2a and b). It can be seen that the Ru particles were uniform in size and shape, and they were dispersed well on the surface of CCHT support. The TEM images of CsBaRuCCHT-IMP and CsRuCCHT-IMP samples (Fig. 2c and d) show that some portions contained small Ru particles, while other portions contained agglomerated large Ru particles, resulting low Ru dispersion in these catalysts. This observation indicates that the Ru dispersion was rather non-homogeneous in the samples prepared by impregnation method. More than 80 particles were examined in the TEM micrographs to calculate the volume/area average particle diameter. The mean particle size of Ru nanoparticles in the RuCCHT-PR sample was between 2.5 to 3.0nm, and this corresponded well the average size of the colloidal Ru nanoparticles (around 5nm). The average particle size of Ru catalysts was also calculated from CO chemisorption experiments and compared with particle sizes measured from TEM results. 3.3 CO chemisorption The CO chemisorption technique was used to determine the Ru metal area and particle size of Ru metal in the synthesized samples. The results from CO chemisorption experiments are presented in Table 1 . From the results, it is observed that the Ru metal area is higher in case of catalysts prepared by polyol reduction method compared to catalysts prepared by impregnation method. A drastic decrease in Ru particle size, especially in double promoted catalyst prepared by polyol reduction method was observed. A similar trend was also observed in HT (without carbon coverage) supported Ru catalysts, but the hike in Ru metal area is less. The evidence for decrease in particle size can be inferred from the XRD patterns in which broad & low intense peaks were observed in catalysts prepared by polyol reduction method. A small difference between the average Ru metal particles size determined from TEM and CO chemisorption was observed; this discrepancy is due to the presence of chlorine in the samples, which could suppress CO chemisorption [39], and then the amount of adsorbed CO decreased. In such a case, the value of particle size based on CO chemisorption was overestimated [40]. 3.4 N2-physisorption The textural properties of unpromoted, single and double promoted CCHT supported Ru catalysts are presented in Table 2 . The data for thermally treated HT were also included for comparison purpose. The thermally treated HT sample possessed surface area of 130m2 g−1, the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm for this sample showed a H3 type hysteresis loop related to pores formed by lamellar structures [Fig 3 (A)]. This observation is very similar as observed in the literature [41]. The formation of mesopores due to removal of CO2 and H2O from the HT structure was reported previously [42]. The CCHT support showed higher surface area than the thermally treated HT support, which is in agreement with the previous report [26]. Carbon coverage treatment changed the pore structure of HT; introduction of carbon and transformation led to increase of total pore volume and pore size. It is possible that the carbon coverage on the surface of MgO-Al2O3 mixed oxide could be responsible for appearance of micropores, which have been proved by pore size distributions of representative samples [Fig. 3(B)]. An increase of surface area was observed after deposition of Ru metal on surface of the CCHT support by polyol reduction method; this is probably due to the fact that the Ru nanoparticles are contributing to the total surface area. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of promoted RuCCHT samples showed different type of isotherm than that of the CCHT support. RuCCHT-PR catalysts showed higher surface area compared to RuCCHT-IMP catalysts. This is due to the fact that the catalyst prepared using polyol reduction method possessed more number of Ru nanoparticles with relatively high dispersion and lower size, which is also confirmed by CO uptake results. The presence of both carbon and agglomerated Ru nanoparticles decreased the total pore volume and pore size of RuCCHT samples, however presence of colloidal sized Ru nanoparticles become advantageous to the generation of micropores, thus the micropore volume increased in case of RuCCHT-PR samples. Addition of single and double promoters caused the gradual decrease of surface area, pore volume and pore radius probably due to formation of agglomerated particles in these catalysts. 3.5 H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) The H2-TPR profiles of single and double promoted Ru catalysts supported on CCHT are shown in Fig. 4 . The TPR profiles of all the CCHT supported Ru catalysts showed almost a single stage reduction of Ru species in the temperature range of 530–686K. However, two stage reduction of Ru species in the temperature range of 473–773K was observed in case of calcined HT (without carbon) supported Ru catalysts and this observation is in accordance with the literature reports [26,27]. Koopman et al. [42] reported that the reduction of Ru4+ (RuO2) to Ru° species in Al2O3-supported Ru catalysts occurs in the range of 450–478K. In other report, Mazzieri et al. [43] observed peaks at around 430K and 470K, which were assigned to the reduction of ruthenium oxychloride and ruthenium oxide, respectively. Betancourt et al. [44] assigned the H2-TPR peaks at 463K and 496K to a well-dispersed Ru phase and to the reduction of RuO2 compound, respectively. In MgO supported Ru catalysts, these peaks appeared in the same temperature range, however the addition of Mg to the Al2O3-supported Ru caused an increase of the interactions between Ru species and the support [45]. The appearance of single stage Ru reduction profile for Ru supported CCHT catalysts can be explained by the fact that the electron deficient graphite lattice in carbon could drift the d-electrons of Ru metal into its lattice and the promoter enables the graphite lattice to take the electrons from it and transport them towards Ru metal [15] leading a strong metal-support interaction between CCHT and Ru [32,33]. Fig. 3 revealed a shift in the T max towards higher temperature in catalysts prepared by polyol reduction method compared to catalysts prepared by impregnation method, which is quite contrary to HT supported catalysts in which T max was shifted towards lower temperature in catalysts prepared by polyol reduction method compared to the impregnated ones. The presence of carbon is responsible for the strong interaction between the Ru metal and the support. The Ru metal dispersion in catalysts prepared by polyol reduction method is high compared to the catalysts prepared by impregnation, so the availability of Ru on the CCHT surface is also more in the former catalysts; which was also confirmed by BET analysis. Hence, more Ru atoms were interacted with CCHT support in case of catalysts prepared by polyol reduction method. This may be the reason for the shift in T max to higher temperature in these catalysts. Another interesting observation from the H2-TPR results is that the H2 consumption is more in catalysts prepared by polyol reduction method than in catalysts prepared by impregnation method. These results confirm the strong metal–support interaction is the reason for shift in T max and single stage reduction of Ru species. 3.6 H2-temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) The adsorption of hydrogen is an integral step in numerous catalytic reactions and it is commonly measured as a means of characterizing metal supported catalysts. Fig. 5 shows the H2-TPD profiles for Ru catalysts supported on CCHT prepared by impregnation and polyol reduction methods. H2-TPD profiles of all the catalysts showed two desorption peaks, which indicates that there are two different binding states in the catalysts. It is known that metal–support interaction plays an important role on the adsorption state of hydrogen on the metal [40]. However, the characteristics of hydrogen adsorption on metal–support systems would be different from that on the single crystals because the metal–support interactions are affected by the factors including particle size, catalyst preparation conditions, reduction temperature etc. According to Lin et al. [29] the adsorption energy of hydrogen on Ru metal is not so strong that hydrogen could desorbs at low temperature and the high temperature peak is attributed to the hydrogen spillover from Ru metal to the support. During desorption process, the hydrogen atoms on the support would migrate back to the metal, then recombine as hydrogen molecules and desorb from the metal surface. From the Fig. 5, it is observed that the high temperature (800K) peak in the TPD profiles along with small hump in RuCCHT-IMP and RuCCHT-PR samples indicate that the desorption temperature of hydrogen on Ru metal and support are very close. It is known that the strong metal-support interaction is the cause for drifting of d-electrons of Ru into the graphite lattice in CCHT [15,35]. From the Fig. 5, it is clear that in Ba promoted Ru catalysts supported on CCHT, the desorption temperature of hydrogen on Ru metal shifted to lower temperature. It was reported that barium has the tendency to decorate the Ru particles to stop the migration of carbon–hydrogen species onto the metal surface, which manifests itself in the enhancing adsorption of hydrogen [46–48]. In BaRuCCHT-PR sample, the enhancement of adsorption of hydrogen on Ru metal was observed and it is due to of higher Ru metal dispersion in this sample. Cesium promoter plays an electron donor role even in its oxidized form as evidenced by XPS experiments [48]. It was also observed that cesium existed more on the surface than in the bulk. The addition of cesium nitrate resulted in the insertion of cesium into support micro pores with the formation of quasi-intercalation cesiumcarbon bonds [49,50]. According to Kowalczyk et al. [51], the cesium promotion occurs at three way contact between Ru and Cs atoms adsorbed on carbon. Hence a strong metal–support interaction exists in Cs promoted catalysts as well, which was observed in Fig 5. In the profile of CsRuCCHT-IMP sample, a low temperature desorption peak was observed, which corresponds to hydrogen adsorbed on Ru metal, but in case of CsRuCCHT-PR sample the intensity of low temperature peak decreased drastically, which could be attributed to high dispersion of Ru metal. In CsBaRuCCHT-IMP sample, only high temperature peak was observed where as in CsBaRuCCHT-PR catalyst both low temperature and high temperature peaks with equal intensities could be observed. The double promoted catalyst prepared by polyol reduction method showed highest activity among all catalysts. Hence not only hydrogen adsorbed on metal but also spilled over hydrogen may be responsible for ammonia synthesis. 3.7 CO2-temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) It was observed that the catalytic activity for ammonia synthesis is related to the basicity of the support; the more basic is the support, the higher is the activity of the catalyst towards ammonia synthesis [16,52]. The basicity of catalyst was evaluated using CO2-TPD measurements. The amount of desorbed CO2 and the temperature of maximum desorption of CO2 are the criteria for the amount and strength of basic sites, respectively. Fig. 6 shows CO2-TPD patterns of Ru catalysts supported on CCHT with single and double promoters. By carbon coverage on calcined Mg–Al HT support, major changes were observed in basicity. The parent calcined Mg:Al HT support showed a two-peak profile one at low temperature (400–500K) and the other at high temperature (<800K) corresponding to weak and strong basic sites. A small shoulder was observed along with high temperature peak around 900K, which has significant role in enhancing the activity for ammonia synthesis [26]. Similarly the CCHT support also showed a two-peak profile, but the desorption peaks shifted towards high temperature and also no shoulder was observed. The barium promoted catalyst, BaRuCCHT-IMP showed similar trend as that of CCHT support, but the cesium promoted catalyst CsRuCCHT-IMP showed two peaks; one at low temperature (500–600K) and the other at high temperature (800K) with a small shoulder. The double promoted samples (CsBaRuCCHT-PR and CsBaRuCCHT-IMP) showed three different desorption peaks corresponding to three different basic sites, however CsBaRuCCHT-PR sample showed broad desorption peaks compared to CsBaRuCCHT-IMP sample in particular the peak corresponding to moderate basic sites. The CO2-TPD results clearly revealed that the catalysts prepared by polyol reduction method are showing remarkably high moderate basic sites compared to their corresponding impregnated catalysts specifically in case of cesium promoted catalysts and cesium and barium promoted catalysts. 3.8 Catalytic activity for ammonia synthesis The synthesized catalysts were tested for ammonia synthesis activity at low reaction temperatures, since chemical industry prefers to develop low temperature active catalysts for ammonia synthesis. The results of ammonia synthesis studies in the temperature range of 523–698K under atmospheric pressure are shown in Fig. 7 . Thermodynamically, the increase of reaction temperature is not favorable for ammonia synthesis. Therefore, it is of great interest to obtain higher equilibrium conversions at lower reaction temperatures under atmospheric pressure. From the Fig. 7, it is clear that the catalysts which are prepared by polyol reduction method are showing better catalytic performance at low temperature compared to the catalysts prepared by impregnation method and also cesium promoted catalysts are showing high activity compared to barium promoted catalysts. All the catalysts showed similar pattern that with increase of reaction temperature, a gradual increase of ammonia formation and reached maximum at optimum temperature. Further increase of temperature resulted in decrease of the activity. This is possibly due to the fact that catalytic and non-catalytic ammonia decomposition processes can takes place at high temperatures. It is interesting to note that different catalysts showed different optimum reaction temperature; Cs promoted samples showed low optimum temperature (CsRuCCHT-PR and CsBaRuCCHT-PR: 598K), on other hand Ba promoted samples showed high optimum temperature (675K). Method of preparation of catalyst also showed an effect in the activity for ammonia formation. At 598K, CsBaRuCCHT-IMP catalyst did not showed any activity, but the CsBaRuCCHT-PR sample showed its highest activity at the same temperature. The CsBaRuCCHT-IMP catalyst showed activity at the same temperature as that of the catalyst BaRuCCHT-IMP. A similar trend was also observed for calcined Ru supported HT catalysts [27]. Fig. 8 shows the TOF of single and double promoted Ru supported CCHT catalysts at different reaction temperatures. The TOF values followed similar trend as ammonia yield, among all the catalysts, CsRuCCHT-PR showed highest TOF values. Single promoted Ru supported HT catalysts showed high reaction rate (Table 1), but the TOF is very low for these catalysts. Double promoted (Cs and Ba) Ru catalysts prepared by polyol reduction method showed considerably high reaction rate and TOF value compared to its corresponding single promoted catalysts [27], but this catalyst has low surface-active metal area and high metal particle size than un-promoted Ru supported catalyst prepared by the same method. This observation indicates that Cs and Ba promotors are playing a role in the catalytic activity for ammonia synthesis. In the literature, the activity of Ru catalysts for ammonia synthesis was explained on the basis of electron donation theory that transformation of electrons from the support or promoter to Ru metal [16]. It was proposed that the electron transfer could lead to decrease the ionization potential of Ru allowing subsequent electron transfer from Ru to the anti-bonding orbits of the N atom, which results the decrease of activation energy for the dissociative adsorption of N2 molecules. It was also reported that the nature of support plays an important role in controlling the Ru crystal morphology and the abundance of B5-type sites, which are known to be active sites for ammonia synthesis [53]. It was indicated that stronger the basicity of support, greater the catalytic activity of Ru catalysts for ammonia synthesis [54]. Mg–Al oxides derived from Mg:Al HT were used as catalysts for many base catalyzed chemical reactions such as Knoevenagel condensations, isomerization, alcohol dehydrogenation etc. [55]; this is due to the fact that these mixed oxides possesses small particle size, large specific surface area, and basic sites with different strength, and these oxides can make Ru surface more electron rich and enhance the dissociation of N2 molecules due to its electron-donating property. The observed activity difference between the RuCCHT-IMP and RuCCHT-PR samples suggests that besides the nature of support, the catalyst preparation method affects the surface Ru characteristics, which generally has an important effect on the catalytic performance. The results from TEM and CO chemisorption measurements are helpful to understand the surface Ru characteristics. The average particle size of Ru nanoparticles in the RuCCHT-PR sample is between 2.5–3.0nm, and this is almost equal to an average size of the colloidal Ru nanoparticles (around 5nm). The average particle size of Ru catalysts was also calculated from CO chemisorption experiments and the results were compared with particle sizes measured from TEM results. RuCCHT-IMP samples showed the agglomerated particle of sizes around 39–41nm. Fernandez et al. [56] concluded that presence of small Ru nanoparticles (approximately 2nm) and also larger particles with a probable size of 7–9nm could help to achieve high catalytic performance in ammonia synthesis. In a very recent report, the same authors [57] reported the difference between the small and Ru particles in the activation of hydrogen at low temperatures. They concluded that the H2 adsorption is slow in case of small Ru particles, which is leading to a low coverage of hydrogen atoms strongly attached to the surface. On other hand, larger Ru particles ensure effective release of active sites because of small energy barrier for hydrogen activation that allow higher mobility of hydrogen atoms. Ramarao et al. [23,25] observed high activities for Ru supported carbon covered Al2O3 catalysts. The authors attributed the activity could be due to high Ru dispersion, enhanced electron transfer from promotors to Ru particles due to presence of the graphite lattice. Additional advantage of presence of carbon in the catalyst is that carbon could decrease the disadvantageous effect of chlorine on H2 adsorption [58]. Hansen et al. [59] reported the advantageous role of some supports for the Ba promotion. They used different characterization results to state that Ba in Ru systems was presented as BaO x phase. They also observed that Ru/MgAl2O4 is poorly promoted compared to systems such as Ru/C and Ru/Si3N4. In another report, Zeng et al. [60] reported that Ba might not solely be in the form of BaO x , but also as Ba(OH)2. It was also observed that the amount of these two phases was depended on the reaction conditions used in the ammonia synthesis. However, it was observed that catalysts which possessed more BaO x phase showed the higher catalytic activity in ammonia synthesis. On other hand, researchers observed a very small promotional effect, when Cs was used alone as a promotor; this is mainly due to fact that Cs x O y species were predominantly located on carbon, whereas the Ru particles remain almost uncovered. However, a full promotional effect was observed after Ru coverage by the Cs x O y species reached to an optimal value (in the range of 0.9–2mmol of Cs/g C+Ru). Jacobsen et al. [61] also observed the differences in the catalytic activities of Ru supported Al2O3 catalysts prepared by impregnation and colloid deposition methods. Ru supported Al2O3 catalysts prepared using Ru colloids offered very good activity; and it is because Ru interacts with the support as metal particles. In contrast, a low and unstable activity was observed for Ru supported Al2O3 catalysts prepared by impregnation method. This is due to the contamination of the Ru metal by small amount of Al which was formed due to dissolution of the Al2O3 during impregnation and participated together with Ru metal. Ru supported CCHT catalysts prepared by impregnation method possessed nearly same CO uptake, active metal area and particle size as the Ru catalysts supported pure HT, but increase in rate of reaction was observed over the CCHT supported catalysts. This is could be attributed to a strong Ru-CCHT support interaction, confirmed by H2-TPD results. The CO uptake and the active surface metal area increased several times for the catalysts prepared by polyol reduction method. This may be attributed to spasmodic increase in surface area of catalysts prepared by polyol reduction method; in addition, presence of strong-metal support interaction, availability of metal and spill over hydrogen and presence of weak and medium basic sites are the contributing factors responsible for high performance of the RuCCHT-PR catalysts for ammonia synthesis. From Fig. 6, it appears that weak basic sites are responsible for high activity and due to possession of high weak basic site densities thus Cs promoted catalysts are showing high activity compared to Ba promoted catalysts. CsBaRuCCHT-IMP catalyst showed only one peak corresponding to moderate basic sites and did not show any considerable high activity. A keen observation reveals that the catalysts prepared by polyol reduction method are showing high activity compared to their corresponding impregnated catalysts specifically in case of Cs promoted catalysts and double promoted catalysts in which moderate basic site densities are remarkably high. Therefore moderate basic sites are one of the factors responsible in enhancing activity of the catalysts for ammonia synthesis. 4 Conclusions Single (Cs or Ba) and double (Cs and Ba) promoted Ru supported CCHT catalysts were prepared by impregnation and polyol reduction methods. Catalytic ammonia synthesis activity for these catalysts was measured at low reaction temperatures under atmospheric pressure. The activity was affected by the Ru particle size and active surface Ru metal area, which is influenced by the method of preparation. The CsBaRuCCHT-PR catalyst showed highest catalytic activity among all Ru supported catalysts. Characterization of catalysts revealed that a strong Ru-CCHT interaction, presence of weak and medium basic sites and presence of small Ru metal particles and spill over hydrogen are responsible factors for high activity. Due to the very high activity, high thermal stability and absence of methanation problems, Cs and Ba promoted Ru catalyst supported on CCHT prepared by polyol reduction may be considered as one of the excellent ammonia synthesis catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Carbon covered hydrotalcite (CCHT) supported Ru catalysts with single (Cs or Ba) and double (Cs and Ba) promoters were prepared by two different methods viz., impregnation (IMP) and polyol reduction (PR) methods using ethylene glycol as solvent. The performance of the catalysts for ammonia synthesis was carried out in the temperature range of 523–698K at atmospheric pressure. The following sequence with respect to the % NH3 (volume/volume) formation was observed; BaRuCCHT-IMP<BaRuCCHT-PR<CsBaRuCCHT-IMP<CsRuCCHT-IMP<CsRuCCHT-PR<CsBaRuCCHT-PR. XRD, TEM, N2-adsorption, H2-TPR, CO chemisorption and TPD of H2 and CO2 techniques were used to investigate the physico-chemical properties of the catalysts and also to establish the reasons responsible for superior catalytic activity of CsBaRuCCHT-PR catalyst. The CO chemisorption and TEM studies revealed that CsBaRuCCHT-PR catalyst possessed the high active Ru metal surface area and small particle size. The highest activity of this catalyst could be attributed to high surface area, low particle size, high active surface metal (Ru) area, and strong Ru–CCHT interaction.
